official-title.#text:
To amend title 38, United States Code, to establish a scholarship program to increase the
			 availability of physicians who provide primary health care services at
			 medical facilities of the Department of Veterans Affairs.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Restoring the Doctors of Our Country through Scholarships Veterans Affairs Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Restoring the Doctors of Our Country through Scholarships Veterans Affairs Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
Congress finds the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
are in dire need of more physicians, with
			 a particular need for doctors trained in primary care specialties.

text.#text: Medical facilities of the
The Health Professionals Educational Assistance Program established by

external-xref.#tail:
of title 38,
			 United States Code, provides educational assistance through scholarships
			 and loan forgiveness for a range of health professionals, however, it does
			 not specifically encourage a commitment to primary care by physicians
			 employed by the

text.#text:
The Reserve Officers’ Training Corps (ROTC) model of education and training is a respected and
			 effective way of meeting the need of the United States for educated and
			 trained officers in the Armed Forces, and it can be applied to train and
			 educate physicians to provide primary care services.

Congress can build off of the Health Professionals Educational Assistance Program and the ROTC
			 model to solve the primary care shortage by providing full-tuition
			 scholarships to students committed to serving the United States as primary
			 care doctors at the

header.#text: Establishment of Restoring the Doctors of Our Country through Scholarships—Veterans Affairs program

external-xref.#tail:
of title 38, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following new
			 subchapter:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall carry out a scholarship program
			 under this subchapter in order to provide for the increased availability
			 of physicians who provide primary health care services at medical
			 facilities of the

. The program shall be

			 Scholarships–Veterans Affairs program (in this subchapter referred to as
			 the

text.#text: As part of the Educational Assistance Program, the

and enter

shall pay—

text.#text: In carrying out the RDOCS–VA program, the

to the participating undergraduate medical program all tuition and costs for the undergraduate
			 medical education of an RDOCS–VA scholar for a period of study not
			 exceeding 48 consecutive months; and
to the RDOCS–VA scholar a cost-of-living stipend, in an amount determined by the
To participate in the RDOCS–VA program, an RDOCS–VA scholar shall agree to—

be admitted into and maintain enrollment in a participating undergraduate medical program in the
			 State of residence of the scholar (or if such State of residence operates
			 no such program, in a participating undergraduate medical program in a
			 State within an associated region);

when enrolled in such program, maintain a minimum level of academic standing (to be determined by
			 the
complete an accredited residency training program in a primary care specialty;
become licensed to practice medicine in the State of residence of the scholar;
receive and maintain board certification in a primary care specialty; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: performing primary care services.

text.#text: complete a five-year post-graduate period of employment by the

shall

are enrolled in an accelerated track family-medicine program; or

text.#text: elect to complete the period of employment described in subsection (b)(6) at a facility of the

An RDOCS–VA scholar shall not be eligible for other assistance under this chapter in connection
			 with the education received under the RDOCS–VA program.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall be liable to the United States for liquidated damages in the
			 amount of $1,500. Such liability is in addition to any period of obligated
			 service or other obligation or liability under the agreement.

text.#text:
An RDOCS–VA scholar (other than a scholar described in subsection (b)) who fails to accept payment,
			 or instructs the participating undergraduate medical program in which the
			 scholar is enrolled not to accept payment, in whole or in part, of a
			 scholarship under the agreement entered into under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: if any of the following occurs:

text.#text:
An RDOCS–VA scholar shall be liable to the United States for the amount which has been paid to or
			 on behalf of the scholar under the agreement entered into under
The scholar fails to maintain an acceptable level of academic standing described in

The scholar is dismissed from the participating undergraduate medical program for disciplinary
			 reasons.

The scholar voluntarily terminates the course of training in such program before the completion of
			 such program.

The scholar fails to become licensed to practice medicine in the State of residence of the scholar
			 during a period of time determined under regulations prescribed by the

Liability under this subsection is in lieu of any service obligation arising under the agreement of
			 the RDOCS–VA scholar.

If an RDOCS–VA officer breaches the agreement by failing (for any reason) to complete the period of
			 obligated service of the officer, the United States shall be entitled to
			 recover from the officer an amount determined in accordance with the
			 formula described in

Any amount of damages which the United States is entitled to recover under this section shall be
			 paid to the United States within the one-year period beginning on the date
			 of the breach of the agreement.

In this subchapter:

term.#tail:
means an appropriately accredited, integrated course of study in which a candidate can complete
			 undergraduate medical education and graduate medical education in six

the area encompassing the boundaries of Delaware and Pennsylvania; or
the area encompassing the boundaries of Maryland, the District of Columbia, and Virginia.
